column5: This is cute but I can‚Äôt help thinking about how badly this cat could fuck that guy up if it wanted to.
That‚Äôs how my eating disorder started. Quit smoking years ago but anorexia decided to stay.
That‚Äôs wonderful. Feeling beautiful makes you look even more beautiful!!
Does this doggo have a neurological deficit or am I free to fully enjoy?? Need answers please.

Is it wrong that I‚Äôm jealous of people who are prescribed and really benefit from that medication? My boyfriend takes it and can‚Äôt even really look at food until after 7pm when it‚Äôs worn off for the day. Only he inhales a normal amount of daily calories in 4 hours where I‚Äôd want to call it a day well starved and go to bed.

I‚Äôm so happy for you. Congratulations on those enormous steps. Please take care and come back and read this post if that gremlin in your brain acts up ‚Äî I know for me it can turn quickly but reminders can snap you out of the mindset. Thinking of you!

What grinds my gears are the ‚Äúbody positive‚Äù mommy entrepreneurs all over Facebook that have no education but try to sell self improvement and weight loss with bogus supplements and still come online and post about how they had cheat meals all weekend and have to ‚Äúget back on track‚Äù, as you say. That‚Äôs not the self love they pretend to be selling. OH man I have so much to say to them but I‚Äôm far too afraid hahahah.

I‚Äôm sorry you‚Äôre struggling right now. It‚Äôs really positive that you have in the past pushed yourself to work on taking care of yourself more. Unfortunately, as I‚Äôm sure you know there isn‚Äôt a pill or a magic fix for an eating disorder. I‚Äôm learning it too, that to get better it‚Äôs your own grit and determination. Of course therapy is really beneficial but at the end of the day you have to make the choice for yourself to defy all the feelings, rules and self hatred that you may feel and do what you know your body needs in spite of it all. 

It‚Äôs such a gruelling process and one that flips in a second from a mindset that you want to do better and then immediately back into the old way of thought. Avoidance of food, restriction and whatever other behaviours that are in the mix are short term solutions to emotional issues and damaging in the long term. Anyone trying to recover has to force themselves into making positive (albeit terrifying) choices in the now to work towards something different. 

It‚Äôs not easy, and I‚Äôm in a similar situation but I really believe that‚Äôs the only way out.
The hair is super cute, love it.

The lower your weight goes, the sicker your body is getting. The eating disorder thoughts become more entrenched, your thinking is less rational and depression/anxiety only get worse. As others have really eloquently put it, your weight isn‚Äôt the problem, how you feel about yourself is. Your eating disorder will not be satisfied until you are gone and that‚Äôs a terribly, fruitless outcome for you and everyone who knows you. 

The only way out is to do what terrifies you and that is a cruel reality. My therapist always likens it to climbing a mountain completely blinded in fog. You have no idea what‚Äôs on the other side, it‚Äôs terrifying and painful but on the other side is life.

I‚Äôm NAD, but I had this issue for years when I was younger. I was out on Prevacid, had a myriad of tests run and nothing really ever came of it. For me, in the end I believe it was anxiety. Whether or not that could be the case for you, of course I don‚Äôt know, but you did mention experiencing anxiety. Food for thought, anyway!

You are beautiful! I have anorexia as well and am still really struggling to eat normally and the fear of weight restoration is holding me back. You‚Äôre inspiring and I hope someday can get to where you are.

I recognize it sounds like you‚Äôre in a really tough spot, walking a fine line between advocating for her and potentially breaching her trust and maybe making her feel more alone. I wonder if it‚Äôs a possibility to bring it up with your father. 

Thank you for being a wonderful sibling. Having someone that loves you is an indispensable resource.
Oh gosh, that‚Äôs terrible!
Mischievous and full of life!
I‚Äôm the same way. I bet no one else would pick up on the flaws that you perceive and would just see a happy face.
It looks soft and shiny, must be doing something right!

My heart breaks reading this. I‚Äôm sorry you‚Äôre watching someone you love struggle and more than that I‚Äôm so saddened to hear of another young girl struggling. Honestly there‚Äôs not a ton that you can do as you‚Äôre not her parent other than continue to be there for her, listen to her when she feels comfortable and let her know you love her and are there for her. As for the family situation that kind of talk needs to stop. It sounds like it could be hard as it‚Äôs other children who are antagonizing her and they may not have the capacity to know the depth of pain they are causing. If there is some way to make it clear that‚Äôs really hurtful without outing her and potentially making her more of a target I would try it. 

Is there a parent aware of what‚Äôs going on? Does your sister realize the issue? Can the two of you eat meals together that are outside of time‚Äôs that she may be antagonized less?

I‚Äôm so sorry you‚Äôre going through that, it sounds like it‚Äôs really scary. It‚Äôs great that you are going to the dentist, because as you know, bulimia is really hard on teeth. You definitely don‚Äôt want to end up at a point where you‚Äôre losing them, so preventative care like you‚Äôll hopefully get is important. As for whether or not a parent may find out - they may or may not. I wonder if they were to find out if it may help you in moving away from purging? 

Either way, I‚Äôm sorry that you‚Äôre struggling and really hoping you get the help you need in the way that you need it. Hang in there, friend.
What beautiful eyes you have. I feel like they‚Äôre kind eyes, what a wonderful feature that is.
That looks like a well taken care of beard!

Beautiful eyes, awesome brows and I wish you had a bigger smile on your face. I‚Äôm also guilty of it, but people never realize how beautiful they are. Don‚Äôt nitpick. Overall, a beautiful girl who I‚Äôm sure is also a kind soul! That‚Äôs a win.

I‚Äôm sorry you‚Äôre feeling so down. Hopefully it passes, I empathize with how hopeless things can feel. In the meantime, for a shallow boost, you‚Äôve got beautiful eyes!
It certainly is complicated.
Oooo it‚Äôs never really enough. That delicious, calorie dense paste will call you back. It always does.

Not to be dismissive, but I think if you‚Äôve taken the time to seek this sub out, you probably have an inkling that at the very least there‚Äôs an unhealthy relationship with food/body. No one here can diagnose you, but disordered relationships are disordered relationships.

It‚Äôs a slippery slope to continue not to eat, I know you probably know that but I just want to reinforce that even though you don‚Äôt want to, if you don‚Äôt want to land yourself needing medical attention it is best to try and get SOMETHING in. I‚Äôm not saying to try and counter the weight loss but enough to let your body have something to function off of. 

Take care of yourself

Yeah, for an organization dedicated to eating disorders I find their information to be really quite basic. Information that you may find on a pamphlet in a doctors office. I also agree that their social media pages are uninspiring and definitely cheesy. That being said I have used the chat option on their website before for support when I was very distressed, so I have some level of appreciation for what they are attempting to do.

Firstly, congratulations on all of your a achievements and the hard work you‚Äôve put in all while managing this illness. The treatment offer sounds similar to the program that I‚Äôve been in (3x now). The decision to take time off is so heart wrenching, I made that choice last semester. I‚Äôm also at university, only one semester from graduating and like you, was barely eating a meal a day. It was getting to the point, for me at least, that I knew getting through the semester may not happen due to increased inability to focus, make decisions and fear of not producing excellent material. 

The way that I weighed the decision was that, for me this has been a 15 year problem and one that isn‚Äôt going anywhere on its own. On one end or the other I will have to deal with it, so the choice became will I continue with school and potentially have my grades/health suffer to make it through (and maybe not) and seek treatment after or step away for a moment, address the issue and hopefully be a better, healthier and more capable version of myself to tackle academics. 

There isn‚Äôt a wrong answer. At the end of the day it comes down to whatever you feel you need more right now ‚Äî to continue study or take a break to get well before continuing. I know how hard it was to make the decision to step away, there was so much guilt and shame but sometimes you need a minute to collect yourself and my university was very supportive. 

If you have any questions about treatment, don‚Äôt hesitate to reach out and good luck with your decision!

I‚Äôm sorry to hear that, I was expecting something much more mild, like ongoing dryness. I am glad for you that it isn‚Äôt terribly affecting you and that you‚Äôre still happy with your decision. Acne, as silly as it is in theory, can be absolutely crippling, so thank god for this medication.

What side effects do you feel you have? It‚Äôs been good for me this far as well. I had a short period of time where I was breaking out in the same area that had been a problem and felt totally betrayed lol but it‚Äôs been good since then, fingers crossed!

I think sometimes I consider that it must appear that way to other people, but then I consider the fact that, for me it‚Äôs not about being skinny to look good. It‚Äôs about hating everything about myself. If you hate everything that you are, the idea that there is more than absolute bare minimum that makes you up is shameful and disgusting. 

I think that everyone‚Äôs eating disorder serves a different function and stems from a different place, but for me I know I‚Äôll never be attractive or interesting or loveable so I atleast don‚Äôt want to draw attention by being large while doing it.

I actually don‚Äôt think I noticed anything beyond an occasional headache. I think I eventually started taking it every other day and then less consistently than that and really didn‚Äôt notice much. What are you finding for side effects?

I might consider asking my psychiatrist about this medication again ‚Äî I seem to be ridiculously sensitive to psychiatric medications and end up with a lot of side effects from all of them I‚Äôve tried in the last 6 months, but sertraline I recall having few.

I‚Äôm in the same boat right now. I ate a regular breakfast and then ate a shit ton at lunch and hate myself now so I really empathize with how you‚Äôre feeling. Logically we both know and would probably tell each other that it‚Äôs ok, it‚Äôs just one day and people eat those things all the time and are just fine. 

I get that feeling a lot too when I‚Äôve eaten more than I‚Äôm comfortable with ‚Äî you just want it gone, but yet purging isn‚Äôt something I‚Äôve done in years and don‚Äôt want to start so it makes it so hard to sit with. Hang in there, try to distract yourself if you can and tomorrow is a new day. You‚Äôre really not alone üíú

I think it definitely did help. Honestly I‚Äôm not sure why I stopped it as I‚Äôm now much worse and have gone through several new drugs. I think I got to a point where I thought to myself, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm doing great, don‚Äôt need this anymore‚Äù.

In my experience, most medications list that weight gain is a potential side effect, even when the probability of that actually happening is low. If members of a clinical trial group gain any weight, even if it‚Äôs quite comparable to the placebo group, it still has to be reported. Another thing I try to keep in mind is the mechanism behind weight gain from medications isn‚Äôt entirely known ‚Äî whether it‚Äôs due to metabolic changes or behavioural changes with food due to feeling better. 

I definitely empathize with the fear, I still agonize over it every time I try a new medication. I have been on sertraline before, and was for years and didn‚Äôt experience any weight gain from it. Best of luck!
